TEMPERATURE AND PRESSURE MEASUREMENT

Boyle’s law states that, at constant temperature, the pressure P of a gas varies inversely with its volume V, or PV = k, where k is a constant. 

Charles’s law states that, at constant pressure, the volume V of a gas is directly proportional to its absolute (Kelvin) temperature T, or 

V/T = k. 

These two laws can be combined to form a single generalization of the behaviour of gases known as an equation of state;

PV = nRT, 

where n is the number of gram-moles of a gas and R is called the universal gas constant. 

Though this law describes the behaviour of an ideal gas, it closely approximates the behaviour of real gases. 

For a monatomic ideal gas (such as helium, neon, or argon), the only contribution to the energy comes from translational kinetic. 

PV = 3/2nRT is used for noble gases. 

The thermometric property used to measure temperature in a constant-volume gas thermometer is that the pressure and volume are directly proportional to temperature. 

PV  T. In a with a constant-volume gas thermometer, temperature is read in terms of pressure. 

Thermocouple has a thermometric property of emf changes with temperature, this enables it to be used in determination of temperature of a body. It is specifically used in measuring very high temperature.

Thermostats are used to control the temperature of a system to maintain a specific range of temperature or to avoid overheating. It is applied in electric heaters, aquarium heaters, pressure cookers and laundry irons to control temperature.

When an open container is exposed to normal atmospheric pressure, the liquid boils when its saturated vapour pressure becomes equal to 1 atmosphere (or 101325 Pa or 101.325 kPa or 760 mmHg). This happens with water when the temperature reaches 100°C. For water to boil at a temperature of 100°C and saturation vapour pressure of 750mmHg, the external pressure should be decreased.

Vapour pressure, pressure exerted by a vapour when the vapour is in equilibrium with the liquid or solid form, or both, of the same substance i.e., when conditions are such that the substance can exist in both or in all three phases. When the vapour of a substance is in equilibrium with its own liquid, it is said to be saturated

For a fixed mass of gas at constant pressure, the volume is directly proportional to the kelvin temperature. Density = Mass/Volume. 

Since density is inversely proportional to the volume and volume is directly proportional to pressure then pressure is inversely proportional to density. 

Hydrometer is different from hygrometer.

A hydrometer is an instrument used to measure the relative density (specific gravity) of different liquids. This achieved by comparing the ratio of the density of the liquid to the density of water. 

Hygrometer is an instrument used for measuring humidity, the moisture content in the air of a specific area
